Legal_Issue: Whether the Refugee Protection Division erred in concluding that Mexican authorities could provide protection
Application_Facts: Applicant faced abuse in Mexico, stayed with aunt, did not file complaints with higher authorities
Decision_Outcome: RPD's decision was reasonable; judicial review dismissed
Grounds_for_Claim: Inability to access state protection in Mexico due to ineffective local police and familial influence
Assessment_Factor: Efforts by Mexico to protect citizens, claimant's failure to pursue higher authorities
Evidence_Used: Evidence of Mexico’s efforts to protect citizens, lack of formal complaints by applicant
Application_Basis: Fear of persecution and lack of state protection in Mexico
Evidence_Assessed: Applicant’s testimony, country condition evidence on Mexico
Governing_Rule: The standard of review for state protection cases is reasonableness
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to file complaints or seek help from higher authorities in Mexico
Cause_Description: Applicant claimed refugee status based on inability to access protection from Mexican authorities
Evidence_Handling: RPD considered available evidence on Mexico’s protective capacity and applicant’s actions
Evidence_Issues: Lack of formal complaints undermines claim of no state protection
Evidence_Assessment: No evidence showed exhaustion of state protection mechanisms in Mexico
Decision_Rationale: RPD’s conclusion was reasonable given evidence of state efforts and claimant’s inaction
Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient evidence that higher authorities would fail to protect
